messages.message: hi team, do we have some super admin user permission in instabase that no customers can have?
`ib-system-admin` and admins in general cc @Pridhvi Vegesna
@Dominic Fannjiang can you add some more context on the use case you need to support?
I want to create some place (either a marketplace app, or perhaps in admin app?) that triggers an API, but I want to make it so only an IB person can trigger it
What does the API do? Why does only an IB person need to trigger it?
You can read a description of the issue here https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Nn_g_gx_jU8cw-4uO_vExxrrH3B1pXkIsRyg41p2HZ4/edit#
but basically, there is a bug in how models generate their predictions and we need to fix it. unfortunately, this fix is not completely idempotent
so I'm curious if we can restrict who can call this API so that we reduce the risk of it being called accidentally when it shouldn't
I'm not sure if this is the best solution for this, but im just curious what the options are

I'm not sure we can currently support semantics of "only an ib employee" can trigger an api/workload.

One thought was to expose the workload in an app that only IB employees have access to (e.g. DM), but on-prem I believe customers have access to DM.

We could hack around some logic at the account roles/permissions level but that might get involved / not be security compliant.
this solution has to apply to both on-prem and saas right?
yes, although if saas deployments are all 23.01+, they would never want this API to be called

@hannah can correct me here but I think all saas environments are fresh installs of 23.01+. Don't understand the issue fully but if we only expect the api to be called in `on-prem` environments, requiring manual ib employee intervention to trigger the api might add a lot of friction.
am happy to join a call to discuss if that helps
Yes @Pridhvi Vegesna youâ€™re correct all of our SaaS deployments were created as a fresh install of 23.01. This should not impact them.
